{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3277252,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-08T20:22:51.085Z","cooked":"

Our programmers have been working on our new swerve chassis for the last few months. Any help with diagnosing the issue described would be greatly appreciated.

They based the code on some from our friends at 5414. They noticed that the chassis spins slightly when attempting to drive in straight line and have been struggling to understand why it does this. None of the mentors have any FRC programming experience and no experience with swerve so we do not know if what they have is as good as it is going to get or if more improvements can/need to be made. They have re-calibrated the module angle quite a few times without any significant change in the results. I believe that it always spins in the same direction.

I found this thread that states that if the COG is not perfectly in the center, the kinematics can be affected.

This video shows the spinning while driving in a straight line. The same behavior is observed when driving on carpet.

They tuned the “teleop rotational P value” and got it to drive with less spin.

We are using SDS MK4i’s with the L2 gearing. We are using NEO’s all around, CANcoders for sensing the module angles, and a Pigeon IMU.

Our code can be found at the following link.

GitHub

GitHub - 8576GoldenWarriors/NEOswerveExample-5414base-main

Contribute to 8576GoldenWarriors/NEOswerveExample-5414base-main development by creating an account on GitHub.

The following are some notes from our programmers.

Swerve update:

Completed

  • The robot is able to strafe and spin in the required directions based on driver input
  • Maximum acceleration was decreased from original value along with the maximum velocity
  • The robot has been switched to field relative with all values of the controller providing the right direction of movement (left and right was previously inverted somewhere along the algorithm, but I decided to just invert the controller input to achieve the same result)
  • A reset button was added to the gyro (button A on he Xbox controller) in order to reset the robot orientation if needed
  • The gyro has been switched from NAVX to Pigeon and recoded to utilize the Pigeon

The problem:

The robot tends to spin while strafing. The reason for this is still unknown, but I believe it is a result of the PID constants not being tuned properly. We’ve logged the outputs onto smart dashboard and have ruled out joystick drift and gyro failure. I’m currently combing through the code and running through the calculations to see where there might be an unwanted value causing the drift.

Swerve Update:

We have added some test statements for outputs from the advantage kit. It seems to have worked as the values are relative to the in time values of smartdashboard. In addition, the robot continues to spin while strafing, however it is not as extreme as previously. This was achieved through tuning of the P value of the robot and can be further enhanced through greater fine tuning to the value.

Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics CD-Media: Papers
Team 449 made our first swerve drive a few months ago, and one of the first things we noticed is that when driving straight and spinning at the same time, the robot always skews in the direction of rotation. I’m sure many of you have also encountered this problem - if you’re wondering whether it’s happening because of an error in your code, the short answer is no. We spent a while trying to debug this issue, and through asking online we settled on the theory that since swerve constant translati…

Thanks. We saw that embedded in the post I linked above.

That post appears to address a drift off the straight line while spinning. We are experiencing spinning when none is being commanded.

I had skimmed through the the post and the linked whitepaper and did not see anything specifically related to our issue. It is possible that the causes of the skew while spinning are similar to our spin while driving straight but we don’t know how to determine that.

We experienced something like this when our wheel alignment was slightly askew.

My team had this problem a lot. However, after we built the rest of the robot, the problem went away. (And lots and lots of fine tuning code)

The problem is amplified due to your weight distribution (the only real weight you have right now is your battery and it’s at the very front/back of your robot).

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-09T01:26:04.682Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":58.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":448674,"topic_slug":"new-swerve-chassis-spinning-while-driving","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62223,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/new-swerve-chassis-spinning-while-driving/448674/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3277650,"name":"rafi","username":"rafi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rafi/{size}/9207_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-09T01:52:28.988Z","cooked":"

It makes sense for the robot to rotate a little while driving if you don’t have closed-loop robot heading control running. Any difference between the left and right driving will cause rotation, and they’ll never match exactly so there will always be some amount of natural rotation. This was an issue even back with tank drive, where one side would run slightly faster than the other when trying to drive straight.

Your proposed solution of using a P loop on the robot heading is spot on. You can use a P loop to take your heading error and output some rotational velocity to be added to your desired ChassisSpeeds to correct for that heading error. The tricky part is knowing what to angle to tell your robot to aim for - this isn’t so bad when driving around, you can just use your turn stick to increase/decrease the desired robot heading (rather than directly commanding angular velocities), but issues come up when your robot hits things. Particularly if you’re trying to slam align to some odd angle, your heading P loop will try to resist the slam align and restore what it “thinks” is your desired heading.

So sometimes it’s better to accept the slight amount of natural rotation, because while having a P controller can fix the slight natural rotation, it also introduces other potential issues.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-01-09T19:04:00.369Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":21.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":448674,"topic_slug":"new-swerve-chassis-spinning-while-driving","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38557,"username":"Bmongar","name":"Brad","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/new-swerve-chassis-spinning-while-driving/448674/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3278554,"name":"Elliot Scher","username":"Gandagorn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gandagorn/{size}/267112_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-09T19:12:36.883Z","cooked":"

another thing to check is if you’re actually running L2 gears. We had an incident where one of our modules was L1 and it made it drift significantly. Especially if you have different gear ratios in your work area, it can be easy to get them mixed up.

Thanks for the suggestion. We only had the 4 modules when they were assembled. It is still possible that one that is not L2 was shipped to us due to human error.
